{{multiple issues| {{primary sources|date=January 2014}} {{advert|date=October 2012}} }} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Use British English|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox company | name = CronLab Ltd. | type = [[Privately held company|Private]] | industry = Telecommunications, IT | foundation = [[Gothenburg]], [[Sweden]] ({{Start date|df=yes|2009}}) | location_city = [[London]], [[United Kingdom]] | products = Web Filter – Hosted |website = http://cronlab.com }}
'''CronLab Limited''' is a [[privately held]] [[limited company]] which provides [[information security]] web filtering software solutions to businesses and consumers either directly or via integration into third party products.
CronLab has offices in [[London]], [[United Kingdom]] and [[Gothenburg]], [[Sweden]].
== History == CronLab, founded in [[Gothenburg]], [[Sweden]], introduced its first [[Anti-spam appliances|Anti-Spam Hardware Appliances]] in 2009. The appliances have received positive reviews from industry media such as ''[[PC Pro]]'',<ref name=PCProReview> {{Citation | title = CronLab Light 1100 anti-spam appliance review | newspaper = [[PC Pro]] | date = 7 March 2011 | url = http://www.pcpro.co.uk/reviews/security-appliances/365746/cronlab-light-1100-anti-spam-appliance | accessdate = 2012-04-08}} </ref> ''[[CRN Magazine]]'',<ref name=crn> {{Citation | title = CronLab Light 1100 anti-spam appliance | newspaper = [[CRN Magazine]] | date = 8 June 2011 | url = http://www.crn.com.au/Review/250849,cronlab-light-1100-anti-spam-appliance.aspx | accessdate = 2012-04-08}} </ref> and ''[[SC Magazine]]'',<ref name=SCMagReview> {{Citation | title = CronLab Pro 2000 Anti-Spam | newspaper = [[SC Magazine]] | date = 25 February 2011 | url = http://www.scmagazineuk.com/cronlab-pro-2000-anti-spam/review/3421/ | accessdate = 2012-04-08}} </ref> which cited the systems for their [[ease of use]] and quick set up, and tested the [[email filtering]] technology as 99% accurate.
In 2010 the company moved its headquarters to [[London]], [[United Kingdom]]. It has also released [[Software as a service|software as a service hosted]] models of the [[spam filtering]] technology<ref name=CompSw> {{Citation | title = Virus i spam ökar explosionsartat | newspaper = [[Computer Sweden]] | date = 2011-08-20 | url = http://computersweden.idg.se/2.2683/1.399016/virus-i-spam-okar-explosionsartat | accessdate = 2012-04-08}} </ref> awarded a recommendation by ''[[Techworld]]'',<ref> {{Citation | title = Stort test: Watchguard • Halon • Cronlab • Symantec • Microsoft • Cleanmail | newspaper = [[Techworld]] | year = 2011 | date = | url = http://softmail.tistory.com/attachment/cfile29.uf@13219D384ED4DE9C217FED.pdf | accessdate = 2012-04-08}} </ref> and hosted [[email archiving]] solutions.<ref>Museum of eMail & Digital Communications: [http://email-museum.com/2011/09/11/cronlab-releases-hosted-email-archiving/ CronLab Releases Hosted Email Archiving]</ref>
CIDE Group, a toy manufacturer, partnered with CronLab on development of a children's [[tablet computer]]. The tablet, called "Kurio", features CronLab's hosted web-filtering and parental controls technology.<ref> {{Citation | title = CronLab enters into a worldwide strategic partnership with CIDE Interactive, part of the CIDE Group of Companies | date = 12 March 2012 | url = http://www.cidetoys.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=60:news-cronlab&catid=3:newsflash&Itemid=39&lang=fr | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160303201213/http://www.cidetoys.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=60%3Anews-cronlab&catid=3%3Anewsflash&Itemid=39&lang=fr | archivedate = 3 March 2016 | accessdate = 2012-04-08 | deadurl = yes | df = dmy-all }} </ref>
CronLab has agreements for distribution in France, Belgium, Switzerland,<ref name=iteCerberus> {{Citation | title = CronLab teams up with new VAD in French speaking markets | newspaper = IT Europa | date = 20 March 2012 | url = http://www.iteuropa.com/News/2012/03-March/CronLab-teams-up-with-new-VAD-in-French-speaking-m.aspx | archiveurl = https://archive.is/20130126122319/http://www.iteuropa.com/News/2012/03-March/CronLab-teams-up-with-new-VAD-in-French-speaking-m.aspx | archivedate = 26 January 2013 | accessdate = 2012-04-08 | deadurl = yes | df = dmy-all }} </ref> Germany,<ref name=SCMagdist> {{Citation | title = CronLab signs Germany, Austria and Switzerland distribution agreement | newspaper = [[SC Magazine]] | date = 2011-03-21 | url = http://www.scmagazineuk.com/cronlab-signs-germany-austria-and-switzerland-distribution-agreement/article/199793/ | accessdate = 2012-04-08}} </ref> Norway,<ref> {{Citation | title = CronLab goes North with Heath Comm | newspaper = IT Distri | date = 18 November 2011 | url = http://www.itdistri.com/EN/blog/2011/11/18/25210/ | accessdate = 2012-04-08}} </ref> Bulgaria, Moldova, Romania,<ref> {{Citation | title = CronLab expands its European coverage with Provision | newspaper = IT Distri | date = 7 June 2011 | url = http://www.itdistri.com/EN/blog/2011/06/07/22960/ | accessdate = 2012-04-08}} </ref> Ireland and the United Kingdom.<ref name=channelproCiRRUS> {{Citation | title = CronLab marks UK expansion with CiRRUS deal | newspaper = IT Europa | date = 2011-03-21 | url = http://www.channelpro.co.uk/news/security/2465/cronlab-marks-uk-expansion-cirrus-deal | accessdate = 2012-04-08}} </ref>
The company’s security products aim to protect against email and web threats such as [[spam (electronic)|spam]], [[spyware]], [[trojan horse (computing)|trojans]] and [[Computer virus|viruses]], and they also provide an [[email archiving]] solution.<ref> {{Citation | last = | first = | title = CronLab launches email archiving tool | newspaper = [[SC Magazine]] | pages = | date = 6 September 2011 | url = http://www.scmagazineuk.com/cronlab-launches-email-archiving-tool/article/211290/ | accessdate = 2012-04-08}} </ref> CronLab’s products support [[multi-tenancy]] and are marketed to [[Internet service provider|ISP]]s, [[Managed services|MSPs]] and [[Information technology consulting|IT consultants]]. Their products can all also be [[White-label product|white labelled]].<ref name=SCMagwhite> {{Citation | last = | first = | title = CronLab releases white-labelled anti-spam solution | newspaper = [[SC Magazine]] | date = 1 February 2010 | url = http://www.scmagazineuk.com/cronlab-releases-white-labeled-anti-spam-solution/article/162778/ | accessdate = 2012-04-08}} </ref>

{{refimprove|date=December 2011}} '''Down payment''' (or '''downpayment''', also called a '''deposit''' in British English), is a payment used in the context of the purchase of expensive items such as a [[car]] and a [[house]], whereby the payment is the initial upfront portion of the total amount due and it is usually given in cash at the time of finalizing the transaction. A [[loan]] or the amount in [[cash]] is then required to make the full payment.
The main purposes of a down payment are to ensure that the lending institution has enough capital to create money for a loan in [[fractional reserve banking]] systems and to recover some of the balance due on the loan in the event that the borrower [[default (finance)|defaults]]. In [[real estate]], the asset is used as [[collateral (finance)|collateral]] in order to secure the loan against default. If the borrower fails to repay the loan, the lender is legally entitled to sell the asset and retain a portion of the proceeds sufficient to cover the remaining balance on the loan, including fees and interest added. A down payment in this case reduces the lender's risk to less than the value of the collateral, making it more likely that the lender will recover the full amount in the event of default.
The size of the down payment thus determines the extent to which the lender is protected against the various factors that might reduce the value of the collateral, as well as lost profits between the time of the last payment and the eventual sale of the collateral.
Furthermore, making a down payment demonstrates that the borrower is able to raise a certain amount of money for long-term investment, which the lender may desire as evidence that the borrower's finances are sound, and that the borrower is not borrowing beyond his or her means.
If the borrower is unable to pay off the loan in its entirety, the down payment amount is forfeited.
==Amounts== In the [[United States]], down payments for home purchases typically vary between 3.5% and 20% of the purchase price.<ref>[http://www.hud.gov/buying/loans.cfm "HUD"]</ref> The Federal Housing Administration has advocated lower down payments since its inception in 1934, and, currently, borrowers that qualify for an FHA loan pay only 3.5% for a down payment. With rising home prices in the years from 2000 to 2007, lenders were willing to accept smaller or no down payment (either through 100% financing, seller-assisted down payment assistance, government down payment providers or by providing a combination of an 80% first and 20% second [[mortgage loan|mortgages]]) so that more individuals could purchase homes as their primary residences. Currently, in the United States, the Department of Veterans Affairs offers complete financing for qualifying veterans. The USDA Home Loan program also offers complete mortgage loans with no down payment. These loans are available as direct or guaranteed loans and are offered to qualifying borrowers purchasing a home in a more rural area. Most state finance housing agencies offer down payment assistance. In 2013, the agencies offer a program that provides assistance to qualifying homebuyers of up to three percent of the loan amount. The money from the state housing agencies can be used for down payment or closing costs.
There is more risk for lenders when individuals purchase a home as an investment property. Therefore, the lender may charge a higher interest rate and expect a higher down payment.

{{Redirect|Double dipping||Double dip (disambiguation){{!}}Double dip}} {{For|Frederick Lugard's book on [[indirect rule]]|Frederick Lugard, 1st Baron Lugard#The Dual Mandate in British Tropical Africa}} A '''dual mandate''' is the practice in which elected officials serve in more than one elected or other public position simultaneously. This practice is sometimes known as '''double jobbing''' in Britain and ''cumul des mandats'' in France; not to be confused with '''double dipping''' in the United States, i.e. being employed by and receiving a retirement pension from the same public authority at the same time. Thus, if someone who is already [[mayor]] of a town or city councillor becomes elected as [[Member of parliament|MP]] or [[senator]] at the national or state legislature and retains both positions, this is a dual mandate.
Dual mandates are sometimes prohibited by law. For example, in [[federal state]]s, federal office holders are often not permitted to hold state office. In states with a [[presidential system]] of government, membership of the [[executive (government)|executive]], the [[legislature]], or the [[judiciary]] generally disqualifies a person from simultaneously holding office in either of the other two bodies. In states with [[bicameralism|bicameral]] legislatures, one usually cannot simultaneously be a member of both houses. The holder of one office who wins election or appointment to another where a dual mandate is prohibited must either resign the former office or refuse the new one.
==European Parliament== A member of the [[European Parliament]] (MEP) may not be a member of the legislature of a [[Member State of the European Union|member state]].<ref name="eu32002D0772">{{cite journal |title=Council Decision of 25 June 2002 and 23 September 2002 amending the Act concerning the election of the representatives of the European Parliament by direct universal suffrage, annexed to Decision 76/787/ECSC, EEC, Euratom|work=Official Journal of the European Communities |volume=L 283 |date=2002-10-21 |url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:32002D0772:EN:NOT |pages=1–4 |id=2002/772/EC,Euratom}}</ref> This dates from a 2002 [[European Union decision]], which came into effect at the [[European Parliament election, 2004|2004 European elections]] in most member states,<ref name="eu32002D0772"/> at the [[Irish general election, 2007|2007 national election]] in the [[Republic of Ireland]],<ref name="eu32002D0772"/> and at the [[European Parliament election, 2009 (United Kingdom)|2009 European elections]] in the [[United Kingdom]].<ref name="eu32002D0772"/>
Originally, MEPs were nominated by national parliamentarians from among their own membership.<ref name="manning74">{{cite news |title= The problems of dual parliamentary loyalty|first=Maurice|last=Manning|work=The Irish Times |date=February 27, 1975|page=6}}</ref> Prior to [[European Parliament election, 1979|the first direct elections in 1979]], the dual mandate was discussed.<ref name="manning74"/> Some advocated banning it, arguing that MEPs who were national MPs were often absent from one assembly in order to attend the other<ref name="manning74"/> (indeed, the early death of [[Peter Michael Kirk]] was blamed by his [[election agent]] on overwork resulting from his dual mandate<ref>{{cite news |title=The Dual Mandate |work=The Irish Times |date=April 21, 1977|page=9|quote=Sir Peter's own election agent has stated categorically that he died from pressure and overwork caused by his dual mandate as an MP at Westminster and a member in Strasbourg.}}</ref>). Others claimed that members with a dual mandate enhanced communication between national and European assemblies.<ref name="manning74"/> There was a particular interest in the dual mandate question in Denmark: [[Eurosceptic]] [[Social Democrats (Denmark)|Danish Social Democrats]] supported a compulsory dual mandate, to ensure that the state's MEPs expressed the same views as the national legislature,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ethesis.net/european_parliament/ep.htm|title=An analysis of the European Parliament’s electoral arrangement(s). A uniform procedure for the elections to the European Parliament? |last=Ziccardi |first=Christiaan |publisher=ethesis|accessdate=October 6, 2009}}</ref> and the government of Denmark supported a compulsory dual mandate when the other eight member states supported an optional dual mandate.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Direct Elections to the European Assembly (European Assembly Elections)|date=1975–76|series=20th Century |journal=House of Commons Sessional Papers|issue=Cmnd. 6399|volume=XII.647|page=9}}</ref> However, a 1976 European Parliament law preparing for the 1979 elections expressly permitted a dual mandate.<ref name="eu41976X1008_01">{{cite journal |title=Act concerning the election of the representatives of the Assembly by direct universal suffrage|work=Official Journal of the European Communities |volume=L 278 |date=October 8, 1976 |url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:41976X1008(01):EN:NOT |pages=5–11 |id=76/787/ECSC, EEC, Euratom}}</ref> In 1978 the German politician [[Willy Brandt]] suggested that one third of MEPs should be national MPs.<ref>{{cite news |title= Problem of Euro elections|first=Walter |last=Ellis|work=The Irish Times |date=February 5, 1977|page=7}}</ref>
==Australia== Dual mandates are rare in [[Australia]]. It is illegal to be a member of any [[Parliaments of the Australian states and territories|state parliament]] and the [[Australian parliament]] simultaneously. A member of a state parliament seeking federal office must resign before seeking election to the [[Government of Australia|Federal]] [[Parliament]]. It is possible but unusual to be a member of a [[local government]] and another [[parliament]].
In 2004 [[Clover Moore]] became the [[Independent (politician)|independent]] [[member for Sydney]] in the [[NSW Parliament]] without resigning as [[Lord Mayor of Sydney]]. The issue of Moore holding both positions had brought the issue to the forefront in Australia and led the premier of [[New South Wales]] in 2012 to propose a new law, dubbed in the media as the "Get Clover bill", which banned this dual mandate. The proposed law was adopted and in September 2012 Moore resigned her NSW seat soon after she was reelected as mayor.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gaynewsnetwork.com.au/news/northern-territory/8916-clover-sadly-farewells-nsw-parliament.html |title=The latest entertainment news for Australia’s LGBTIQ community |publisher=Gay News Network |date= |accessdate=2013-08-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120922144157/http://gaynewsnetwork.com.au/news/northern-territory/8916-clover-sadly-farewells-nsw-parliament.html |archivedate=2012-09-22 |df= }}</ref>
==Belgium== As in neighboring France, the culture of dual mandates is very strong in Belgium and that country currently has one of the highest percentage of dual mandate holders (MPs, aldermen, municipal councilors) in the world. During the 2003–2009 period, 87.3% of members of the Walloon (French-speaking) Parliament held dual mandates, followed by 86,5% in the Flemish (Dutch-speaking) Parliament, 82,0% in the Chamber of Representatives (the Federal lower house) and 68.9% in the Senate. During that same period, 76.5% of all European Parliament MPs from Belgium held dual mandates.
More than one fifth of all Belgian MPs were mayor at the same time with, by far, by the highest proportion (40%) to be found in the Walloon Parliament.<ref>Gert-Jan Put and Ine Vanlangenakker, "The extent of multiple office-holding in Belgium (2003-2009). An exploration of the underlying reasons." PhD Thesis, Katholieke Universiteit Leuven (2010), pp. 10–11.</ref>
==Canada== In Canada dual mandates are rare and are frequently barred by legislation at the federal, provincial, or territorial level. At the federal level, section 39 of the [[Constitution Act, 1867]] prevents a [[Senate of Canada|Senator]] from being elected as a [[House of Commons of Canada|Member of Parliament]]; similarly, s. 65(c) of the [[Canada Elections Act]] makes members of provincial or territorial legislatures ineligible to be candidates to the House of Commons. At the provincial level, the situation varies from one province to another.
In other circumstances, an elected official almost always resigns their first post when elected to another. Dual representation has occurred occasionally when the member was elected to a second office shortly before their other term of office was due to expire anyway and whereby the short time frame would not merit the cost of a special [[by-election]]. In 1996, for example, [[Jenny Kwan]] continued to be a [[Vancouver]] city councillor after being elected to the [[Legislative Assembly of British Columbia|provincial legislature]]. The British Columbia legislature had debated a "Dual Office Prohibition Act" which failed to pass [[second reading]].
In the first few years after [[Canadian Confederation|Confederation]] in 1867, however, double mandates were common. In the first [[House of Commons of Canada|House of Commons]], there were fifteen Members of [[Parliament of Canada|Parliament]] from [[Quebec]] who simultaneously held seats in the [[National Assembly of Quebec]], including the [[Premier of Quebec|Premier]] [[Pierre-Joseph-Olivier Chauveau]]. There were also four members of Parliament from [[Ontario]] who also held seats in the [[Legislative Assembly of Ontario]], including the first two [[Premier of Ontario|Premier]]s, [[John Sandfield Macdonald]] and [[Edward Blake]]. Other prominent federal politicians with double mandates included [[George-Étienne Cartier]], [[Christopher Dunkin]], [[Hector Langevin]], the second [[Premier of British Columbia]] [[Amor de Cosmos]], and two members from [[Manitoba]], [[Donald Smith, 1st Baron Strathcona and Mount Royal|Donald Smith]] and [[Pierre Delorme]].<ref>{{cite book |title=Ex Uno Plures: Federal-Provincial Relations in Canada, 1867-1896 |author=Garth Stevenson |page=330 |publisher=McGill-Queen's University Press |year=1993 |isbn=0-7735-1633-6 |edition=paperback |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3mbJIbrmfgUC&pg=PA330&lpg=PA330}}</ref> Another famous example is that of the ''de facto'' leader of the [[Liberal Party of Canada|Liberals]], [[George Brown (Canadian politician)|George Brown]], who ran for both federal and provincial seats in 1867. Brown lost both elections, and soon thereafter began campaigning for the prohibition of double mandates.
The double mandate was prohibited from the start in [[Nova Scotia]] and [[New Brunswick]]; it was abolished in Ontario in 1872, in Manitoba in 1873, and in 1873 the federal parliament passed a law against it; Quebec passed its own law abolishing it in 1874.<ref>{{cite book |title=The French-Canadian idea of Confederation, 1864-1900 |author=A. I. Silver |page=122 |edition=second paperback |publisher=University of Toronto Press |year=1997 |isbn=0-8020-7928-8 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tipNL7l7FbQC&pg=PA122&lpg=PA122}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |work=Parliament of Canada |title=House of Commons Procedure and Practice |editor1-first=Robert |editor1-last=Marleau |editor2-first=Camille |editor2-last=Montpetit |year=2000 |chapterurl=http://www.parl.gc.ca/MarleauMontpetit/DocumentViewer.aspx?DocId=1001&Sec=Ch04&Seq=17&Language=E#fn81 |chapter=4. The House of Commons and Its Members |isbn=2-89461-378-4 |accessdate=February 20, 2012}}</ref>
However, dual mandates within a province remained legal. From 1867 to 1985, 305 mayors were also members of the Quebec legislative assembly (MLA). The two best-known cases were those of S.N. Parent who was simultaneously mayor of Quebec City (1894-1906), MLA and Premier of Quebec (1900-1905). Longtime Montreal Mayor Camilien Houde (1928–32, 1938–40) was also simultaneously MLA for a total of 2 /1/2 years during his mandates as mayor. However that type of dual mandate had virtually ceased when laws adopted in 1978 and 1980 prohibited MLAs from holding any local mandate.
==Finland== It is common for the MPs of the [[Parliament of Finland|Finnish Parliament]] to hold a mandate as a member of their local municipal council as well. 79 percent of MPs elected to parliament in 2011 were also municipal council members.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kunnat.net/fi/Kuntaliitto/media/tiedotteet/2011/04/Sivut/eduskunnassa-yha-enemman-kunnanvaltuutettuja.aspx |title=Eduskunnassa yhä enemmän kunnanvaltuutettuja |publisher=Kunnat.net |date= |accessdate=2013-08-29}}</ref>
==France== [[File:2014-11-22 16-21-42 commemoration.jpg|thumb|The MP-mayor of Belfort and the senator-mayor of Beaucourt at a ceremony in 2014]] The ''' ''cumul des mandats'' ''' ({{IPA-fr|kymyl dɛ mɑ̃da|lang}}, {{literally}} ''accumulation of mandates'') is a common practice in the [[French Fifth Republic]] (1958–present).<ref>At the time Pierre Mauroy was prime minister (1981–84), he kept his job as [[Mayor (France)|mayor]] of Lille, one of France's largest cities, without anyone objecting. France has had legions of députés-maires, sénateurs-maires and ministres-maires.</ref> It consists of simultaneously holding two or more elective offices at different levels of government — local, regional, national and European — as mayors, MPs, senators, Members of the European Parliament, and [[President of the General Council]] in their home regions.<ref>{{cite book| last=Gidea |first=Robert |year=2002 |title=France since 1945 |location=Oxford |publisher=Oxford University Press |isbn=0-19-219246-9 |page=240 }}</ref> Sometimes, officials hold as many as four positions.<ref>{{cite book |last=Nadeau |first=Jean-Benoît |author2=Julie Barlow |title=Sixty million Frenchmen can't be wrong: why we love France but not the French |year= 2003|publisher=Sourcebooks |location=Naperville, Illinois |isbn=1-4022-0045-5 |page=56 }}</ref> While officials may not be elected to more than one office at the same level (such as being both an MP and a senator), they may hold offices in any combination at the municipal, departmental, regional, national and European levels. The ''cumul des mandats'' is controversial in France, being accused of fostering [[absenteeism]] and [[cronyism]].
Several laws to limit the practice have been introduced in recent decades. By far the most coveted local mandate is that of mayor, traditionally a highly prestigious function in France.
A hotly debated law to prohibit all dual mandates, to take effect in 2017, was adopted in July 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/politique/article/2013/07/05/cumul-des-mandats-l-assemblee-adopte-la-principale-mesure-du-projet-de-loi_3442825_823448.html|title=Non-cumul des mandats : le projet de loi adopté à l'Assemblée|date=5 July 2013|publisher=|via=Le Monde}}</ref> Following the adoption of the law, former President Sarkozy and other members of the opposition UMP party have declared that if elected in 2017, their party would revise or even revoke that law.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lefigaro.fr/politique/2014/01/19/01002-20140119ARTFIG00186-la-droite-table-sur-l-abrogation-du-texte-en-cas-de-retour-au-pouvoir-en-2017.php|title=Cumul des mandats : la droite reviendrait sur le texte en cas de retour au pouvoir|first=Jean-Baptiste|last=Garat|date=19 January 2014|publisher=|via=Le Figaro}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bfmtv.com/politique/sarkozy-pret-a-supprimer-la-loi-sur-le-non-cumul-des-mandats-940126.html|title=Sarkozy prêt à supprimer la loi sur le non-cumul des mandats?|first=|last=BFMTV|publisher=}}</ref> Many Socialist Party MPs and senators have also expressed their unease with the law imposed by President Hollande and might welcome a review of the law. In the meantime, the ubiquitous 'député-maire' (MP and mayor) and 'sénateur-maire' are still familiar figures of the French political scene.
===Conditions regarding multiple mandates in France=== *The [[President of France|President of the Republic]] cannot hold any other office during their tenure.
'''Multiple mandates at the legislative level'''
Parliamentary mandates are incompatible with each other:
*Member of the [[National Assembly of France]] *Member of the [[Senate of France]] *Member of the [[European Parliament]]
A member from one of the above assemblies can not combine its mandate with more than one of the following mandates :
*Member, vice-president or president of a [[General councils (France)|General Council]] *Member, vice-president or president of a [[Regional councils of France|Regional Council]] *Councillor, deputy-mayor, or [[Mayor (France)|mayor]] of a commune of more than 3,500 inhabitants *Councillor of Paris (The "[[Council of Paris]]" is at the same level a municipal council and a general council, because Paris has a special status, Municipality and [[Department (administrative division)|Département]] at the same level) *Councillor in the [[Corsican Assembly]] (Corse has a regional special status)
Exceptions: They can hold a third office in a town of less than 3,500 inhabitants.
They may also hold a third office as a councillor, vice-president or president of an [[Urban communities in France|Urban community]], an [[Agglomeration communities in France|Agglomeration community]] or a ''[[Communauté de communes]]'', as these terms are elected by indirect universal suffrage, by municipal councils from among the councillors.
For example, a member of the National Assembly has the right to be general/regional councillor or [[President of the Regional Council (France)|President]] of a regional/general council. They cannot hold a third office unless they are the mayor, deputy mayor or municipal councillor of a city of less than 3,500 inhabitants.
In 2008, 85% of members of parliament held multiple posts <ref>Sciolino, Elaine, [https://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/13/world/europe/13france.html?_r=1&th=&emc=th&pagewanted=all French Cabinet Position Not Enough? Then Try Mayor], [[The New York Times]], January 13, 2008. Accessed March 26, 2012.</ref> Following the June 2012 legislative elections, it was still the case that 85% of all National Assembly members (438 deputies out of 577) held a double mandate (often as mayor of a mid- to large-size city) and 33 have four mandates.<ref>{{cite web|author=Nom * |url=http://bigbrowser.blog.lemonde.fr/2012/07/11/pastiche-le-cumul-des-mandats-une-addiction-qui-se-soigne/ |title=PASTICHE – Le cumul des mandats, une addiction qui se soigne | Big Browser |publisher=Bigbrowser.blog.lemonde.fr |date= |accessdate=2013-08-29}}</ref> Currently, out of 348 senators, 152 are also mayors.<ref>{{cite web|author=Nom * |url=http://jeandumonteil.blog.lemonde.fr/2012/05/14/lengagement-de-la-fin-du-cumul-des-mandats-sera-t-il-tenu/ |title=L’engagement de la fin du cumul des mandats sera-t-il tenu ? | EXTRATERRITORIAL |publisher=Jeandumonteil.blog.lemonde.fr |date= |accessdate=2013-08-29}}</ref>
'''The accumulation of local mandates'''
They cannot have more than two local mandates.
The following mandates are incompatible each other:
*[[Mayor (France)|Mayor]] *[[President of the General Council]] *[[President of the Regional Council (France)|President of the Regional Council]]
For example, an elected official cannot be mayor and President of the Regional Council. However, all other local mandates are cumulative. A mayor can also be a general councillor and a president of a Regional Council can also be deputy-mayor of a city.
Exceptions are the same as those for parliamentarians (Cities of less than 3,500 inhabitants and the intercommunalities)
'''The accumulation of mandates and governmental functions''' [[File:2014-11-22 16-21-42 commemoration.jpg|thumb|left|The [[Damien Meslot|MP-mayor]] of Belfort and the {{ill|Cédric Perrin|fr|Cédric Perrin (homme politique)}} senator-mayor of Beaucourt at a ceremony in 2014]] A member of the French government cannot be a member of any assembly. However, he may retain any local mandate he or she holds. A cabinet minister can exercise a maximum of two local mandates in addition to his or her government function.
For example, the Prime Minister, a Minister or Secretary of State can be [[Mayor (France)|mayor]], or President of a general, regional or intercommunal council or sit in one of these assemblies.
Currently, over two-thirds of the members of the French government are engaged in one or two more local mandates.
===Purpose and frequency=== {{POV section|date=March 2015}} The rationales for holding multiple offices are varied. Holding a seat in the Senate, National Assembly, or European Parliament gives local [[Mayor (France)|mayors]] a valuable method of tapping funds to develop their home cities and regions.<ref name="Gildea, pg. 240">Gildea, pg. 240</ref> It also can give opportunities to curry favor with other important officials, with opportunities at each level.<ref name="Nadeau and Barlow, pg. 56">Nadeau and Barlow, pg. 56</ref> Salaries for positions can be combined (to a point) as well.<ref name="Nadeau and Barlow, pg. 56"/> For politicians with national ambitions, retaining a position in a local town can give them a down-to-earth aura that can appeal to voters. These advantages have made politicians very wary of reducing the practice of the ''cumul'' with legislation despite other moves to end perceptions of favoritism and corruption among politicians.<ref>Gildea, pg. 281</ref>
It has been common practice in France since the [[French Third Republic]] (1870). But there are also many cases of "cumul" before this period, for example, the writer [[Alexis de Tocqueville]] was a member from 1839 to 1851. In 1849 he was appointed Foreign Affairs minister, and at the same time he was elected [[President of the General Council]] of [[Manche]] from 1849 to 1851 (councillor from 1842 to 1852).
There are several reasons for this phenomenon, and one of them is that France has a long tradition of centralization, compared to countries such as Germany, Italy, and Spain. Local governments have less power and skills than that the "Länder" of Germany, or "Autonomous Communities" of Spain. The local mandates in France are less important than in other countries, and therefore politicians have more time to devote to a parliamentary mandate.
The ''cumul'' is a widespread practice and has grown much more prevalent in modern France. In 1946, 36 percent of deputies in the National Assembly held an additional office.<ref name="Gildea, pg. 240"/> By 1956, this number had already increased to 42 percent<ref name="Gildea, pg. 240"/> and by 1970, 70 percent of deputies held an additional elected office; in 1988, 96 percent did.<ref name="Gildea, pg. 240"/>
Many of the most prominent politicians in France make use or have made use of the ''cumul''. [[Jacques Chirac]] served as [[List of mayors of Paris|Mayor]] of [[Paris]] between 1977 and 1995. During this same time, Chirac also served as a deputy in the National Assembly from [[Corrèze]], briefly as [[Member of the European Parliament]], and even as [[Prime Minister of France|Prime Minister]] between 1986 and 1988.<ref name="Nadeau and Barlow, pg. 56"/> Former Prime Minister [[Pierre Bérégovoy]] served concurrently as mayor of [[Nevers]] and deputy of [[Nièvre]] in the mid-1980s.
====An example : the accumulation of four electoral mandates==== [[File:20110300 Emboîtement et cumul des mandats d'Yves Jégo.PNG|thumb|[[Yves Jégo]]'s four mandates, between March 2010 and July 2011.]] According to French law<ref>[http://www.interieur.gouv.fr/sections/a_votre_service/elections/les_elections_en_france/cumul-mandats "French Interior Ministry"] "Le cumul des mandats électoraux" (in French)</ref> against accumulation of electoral mandates, [[Yves Jégo]] should have resigned from one of the following mandates before the 21st of April 2010 (one month after the Regional elections) : *Member of the [[National Assembly of France]] for [[Seine-et-Marne]] *Regional councillor of [[Île-de-France (region)|Île-de-France]] *[[Mayor (France)|Mayor]] of [[Montereau-Fault-Yonne]] But giving as a pretext a legal complaint from the [[Front National (France)|Front National]]'s candidates, he hold the three of them during more than one year, plus his local mandate of president of the « [[communauté de communes]] des deux fleuves » ([[Communauté de communes des Deux Fleuves|CC2F]]).
===Recent and current status of ''cumul'' in the French government=== [[Lionel Jospin]] (Prime Minister from 1997 to 2002) imposed on his government ministers an unwritten rule of having no local office. For example, [[Catherine Trautmann]] stepped down as [[Mayor (France)|Mayor]] of [[Strasbourg]] (while remaining a member of the city council) to become [[Minister of Culture (France)|Minister of Culture]]; conversely, [[Martine Aubry]] stepped down from the [[Minister of Labour (France)|Ministry of Labour]] when elected Mayor of [[Lille]] in 2001. This rule was more or less upheld by [[Jacques Chirac]] during the governments of [[Jean-Pierre Raffarin]] and [[Dominique de Villepin]] for the 2002-2007 term, with a few notable exceptions ([[Jean-François Copé]] was mayor of [[Meaux]], [[Nicolas Sarkozy]] was [[President of the General Council|President]] of the [[Hauts-de-Seine]] General Council); for instance, [[Philippe Douste-Blazy]] had to step down from the [[Toulouse]] mayorship upon joining the government.
{{As of|2007}}, no such rule was stated for the [[François Fillon]] government: [[Alain Juppé]], former Minister for Development was mayor of [[Bordeaux]], and was defeated in his National Assembly constituency (a third cumulative mandate) by 50.9% to 49.1% of the votes by the [[Socialist Party (France)|Socialist]] candidate. Additionally, [[Hervé Morin]], the [[Minister of Defense (France)|Minister of Defense]], is mayor of [[Épaignes]], and [[Éric Besson]], Minister of Immigration and National Identity, is the mayor of [[Donzère]].
==Hong Kong== In Hong Kong, dual mandate is common for members of the territory's [[Legislative Council]], who serve concurrently as members of one of the territory's eighteen district councils. Before the abolition of the two municipal councils in the territory in 1999, it was common for politicians to serve concurrently at all three levels.
==Ireland== The instability caused by the close result of the [[Irish general election, 1981|1981 general election]] was exacerbated by the number of government [[Teachta Dála|TD]]s who also served as MEPs and for whom the opposition refused [[Pair (parliamentary convention)|pairing]] when they were abroad.<ref>{{cite book|last1=O'Connor|first1=Tom|last2=O'Halloran|first2=Anthony|last3=Pattison|first3=Seamus|title=Politics in a Changing Ireland 1960-2007: A Tribute to Seamus Pattison|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ujipx7kGF70C&pg=PA49|accessdate=28 November 2014|date=2008-01-01|publisher=Institute of Public Administration|isbn=9781904541691|page=49|chapter=A career politician}}</ref> This led to further elections [[Irish general election, February 1982|in February 1982]] and [[Irish general election, November 1982|again in November]].
In 1991, [[Government of Ireland|cabinet ministers]] and [[Minister of State (Ireland)|junior ministers]] were prohibited from serving as [[Local government in the Republic of Ireland|local councillors]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/eli/1991/act/11/section/13/enacted/en/html#sec13|title=Local Government Act, 1991, Section 13|work=[[Irish Statute Book]]|accessdate=3 June 2016}}</ref> The prohibition was extended to other [[Oireachtas]] members by the Local Government (No. 2) Act 2003, an amendment to the [[Local Government Act 2001]].<ref>{{cite book |chapterurl=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/2003/en/act/pub/0017/print.html#sec2 |title=Local Government (No. 2) Act 2003 |date=June 2, 2003 |series=[[Irish Statute Book]] |chapter=§2 Amendment of Principal Act — insertion of new section 13A |accessdate=2009-10-06}}</ref> Attempts to include it in the 2001 Act failed after a rebellion by [[Fianna Fáil]] [[backbencher]]s;<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.independent.ie/opinion/analysis/no-political-will-to-rock-the-cosy-boat-that-is-the-seanad-502066.html |title=No political will to rock the cosy boat that is the Seanad |last=Murphy |first=John A |date=14 July 2002|work=Sunday Independent |quote=The councillor lobby which stymied Noel Dempsey's plans to end the dual mandate |accessdate=16 April 2010|location=Dublin }}</ref> the 2003 Act passed after a compensation package was agreed for those losing out.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/news-in-brief-215369.html |title=Local government needs independent 'fiscal autonomy' |last=Geaney |first=Louise |date=2 June 2003 |work=Irish Independent |quote=The Local Government Bill 2000 proposed to abolish the dual mandate but the Act dropped the idea, only for it to be re-introduced — with a handy €12,800 sweetener — in 2003. |accessdate=16 April 2010 |location=Dublin }}</ref>
The 2001 Act prohibited being a member of multiple county or city councils, or multiple [[List of cities, boroughs and towns in the Republic of Ireland|town council]]s, or both a town and city council.<ref>{{cite book |chapterurl=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/2001/en/act/pub/0037/sec0014.html |title=Local Government Act 2001 |year=2001 |series=Irish Statute Book |chapter=§14. Prohibition on multiple membership of local authorities |accessdate=April 15, 2010 }}</ref> [[Brian O'Shea (politician)|Brian O'Shea]] was a member of both [[Waterford City Council]] and [[Waterford County Council]] until 1993. County councillors were allowed to sit on a town council,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.citizensinformation.ie/categories/government-in-ireland/local-and-regional-government/councillors |title=Membership of local authorities in Ireland |date=3 December 2009 |work=Government in Ireland |publisher=Citizens Information Board |accessdate=16 April 2010 |location=Dublin }}</ref> and many did so. The 2003 Act provided that a candidate elected simultaneously to a forbidden combination of local councils has three days to choose which seat to take up, with the other or others then being considered vacant.<ref>{{cite book |chapterurl=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/2003/en/act/pub/0017/sec0006.html |title=Local Government (No. 2) Act 2003 |date=June 2, 2003 |series=Irish Statute Book |chapter=§6 Amendment of Local Elections Regulations 1995 |accessdate=2009-10-06}}</ref> The [[Local Government Reform Act 2014]] abolished town councils and instead subdivided most counties into [[municipal district (Ireland)|municipal district]]s; the county council's members are the district councillors for all districts within the county.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.environ.ie/en/LocalGovernment/LocalGovernmentReform/|title=Local Government Reform|year=2014|publisher=Department of the Environment, Community & Local Government|accessdate=29 May 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/2014/en/act/pub/0001/sec0019.html|title=Local Government Reform Act 2014, Section 19|work=[[Irish Statute Book]]|accessdate=29 May 2014}}</ref>
Some members of the Irish republican party [[Sinn Féin]] held the office as a [[Member of The Northern Ireland Assembly]] and [[Member of Parliament (UK)|Member of Parliament]] within the respective houses. [[Martin McGuinness]], former [[Deputy First Minister of Northern Ireland]] held the office as Member of the Northern Ireland Assembly and simultaneously was a MP in the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]]. However, in 2012 Sinn Féin committed to end dual jobbing; this resulted in McGuinness' resignation from the House of Commons in 2013.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-northern-ireland-20871049|title=Sinn Fein's Martin McGuinness resigns as Mid-Ulster MP|date=2012-12-30|newspaper=BBC News|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-11-04}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/martin-mcguinness-hands-in-his-resignation-for-mp-position-735995-Dec2012/|title=Martin McGuinness resigns as MP|last=Croffey|first=Amy|newspaper=TheJournal.ie|access-date=2016-11-04}}</ref>
==Spain== Per the [[Spanish Constitution]], legislators in the [[List of Spanish regional legislatures|regional assemblies]] of the [[Autonomous Communities of Spain|Autonomous Communities]] are barred from being elected to a seat in the [[Congress of Deputies]], the lower house of the [[Cortes Generales]]. More precisely, regional legislators can run for the seat, but if elected they must choose between the regional and national parliaments. Nevertheless, members of lower tiers of the Spanish decentralized structure, such as provincial councillors or members of local councils, including mayors, can and have held seats in the Congress of Deputies. The rule barring regional legislators does not apply to the upper house of the Cortes, the [[Spanish Senate|Senate]]: in fact, regional legislatures are entitled to appoint a varying number of members from their ranks to the Senate, according to the population of the region. Currently, the Autonomous Communities appoint 56 Senators, the other 208 being directly elected in [[Elections in Spain|general elections]].
==United Kingdom== At the EU level, prior to the [[European Parliament election, 2009|2009 European Parliament elections]], there were a small number of [[Member of the European Parliament|members of the European Parliament]] who were also members of the [[House of Lords]].<ref>[http://www.bundeswahlleiter.de/europawahl2004/downloads/decisionandact.pdf ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060708163144/http://www.bundeswahlleiter.de/europawahl2004/downloads/decisionandact.pdf |date=July 8, 2006 }}</ref> However, it is now European law that a member of the [[European Parliament]] (MEP) may not be a member of the legislature of a [[Member State of the European Union|member state]].<ref name="eu32002D0772"/> This, with regard to the United Kingdom, therefore applies to the House of Commons and the House of Lords, as the constituent bodies forming that member state's legislature. As it is impossible to disclaim a [[life peerage]], it has been ruled that peers (who sit as members of the House of Lords) must take a "leave of absence" from the Lords in order to be an MEP; this is also the procedure for when a peer is the UK's [[European Commissioner]], which has in recent times usually been the case.
There have been members of the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] also holding seats in the devolved bodies in [[Scottish Parliament|Scotland]], [[National Assembly for Wales|Wales]] and [[Northern Ireland Assembly|Northern Ireland]]. The November 2009 report by the [[Committee on Standards in Public Life]] into [[United Kingdom Parliamentary expenses scandal|the controversy surrounding MPs' expenses]] noted that "double jobbing" was "unusually ingrained in the political culture" of Northern Ireland, where 16 of 18 MPs were MLAs, compared to one Scottish MP being an MSP ([[First Minister of Scotland|First Minister]] [[Alex Salmond]]), and no Welsh MPs being AMs.<ref name="CSPL">{{cite book |url=http://www.public-standards.gov.uk/Library/MP_expenses_main_report.pdf#page=97 |title=MPs' expenses and allowances; Supporting Parliament, safeguarding the taxpayer |date=November 2009 |accessdate=15 April 2010 |author=Committee on Standards in Public Life |series=House of Commons papers 2009 |volume=7724 |others=Chaired by Sir [[Christopher Kelly (civil servant)|Christopher Kelly]] |page=95 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101214231245/http://www.public-standards.gov.uk/Library/MP_expenses_main_report.pdf#page=97 |archivedate=14 December 2010 |df= }}</ref> The Committee recommended that Westminster ban multiple mandates from the 2011 assembly elections.<ref name="CSPL"/> Parties in Northern Ireland agreed to a ban from the 2015 elections.<ref name="CSPL"/> The ability to dual mandate between the Assembly of Northern Ireland and the House of Commons (or the Irish [[Dáil Éireann]]) ended as from the [[Northern Ireland Assembly election, 2016]] following the [[Northern Ireland (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 2014]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2014/13/section/3|title=Northern Ireland (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 2014|publisher=}}</ref> The [[Wales Act 2014]] also applied a similar restriction on the National Assembly for Wales (in that its members cannot also be members of the House of Commons) as from the assembly election in 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://services.parliament.uk/bills/2014-15/wales.html|title=Wales Act 2014 — UK Parliament|publisher=}}</ref>
Nothing in UK law prohibits a member of the House of Commons or the House of Lords from being simultaneously a mayor, council leader, or other locally elected official. Thus [[Ken Livingstone]] remained MP for [[Brent East (UK Parliament constituency)|Brent East]] until the dissolution of Parliament despite his election as [[Mayor of London]] a year before.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/davehillblog/2010/jan/05/boris-johnson-london-mayor-mp-simultaneously|title=Boris Johnson: simultaneous Mayor and MP?|first=Dave|last=Hill|date=5 January 2010|publisher=|via=The Guardian}}</ref> [[Boris Johnson]] resigned his seat as MP for [[Henley (UK Parliament constituency)|Henley]] on being elected mayor in 2008, but became an MP again in 2015, a year prior to the end of his second term as mayor (he did not seek a third term). [[Sadiq Khan]], elected as the Labour mayor in the [[London mayoral election, 2016|2016 election]], resigned his seat as MP for [[Tooting (UK Parliament constituency)|Tooting]] soon after his election to the mayoralty.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-34218390|title=Sadiq Khan wins Labour London mayoral selection|date=11 September 2015|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}}</ref> Numerous members of the [[House of Lords]] however hold positions in local government.
At a lower level, it is common for people to hold seats on both [[administrative geography of the United Kingdom|a district council and a county council]]. Several MPs have also retained their council seats, most often until the expiration of their terms;<!--John Hemming, for three years; Craig Whittaker, for one--> [[Mike Hancock (British politician)|Mike Hancock]] simultaneously held a council seat and a seat in Parliament between his election to Parliament in 1997 and his defeat in the local elections in 2014.
==United States== ''The term '''dual mandate''' is also applied to the twin objectives of the [[Federal Reserve Bank]]: to control inflation and promote employment.''
The practice is banned by [[State constitution (United States)|the constitutions]] of many [[U.S. state]]s, but as of 1992 it was still legal in [[Connecticut]], [[Illinois]], [[New Jersey]] and [[New York (state)|New York]]. The [[U.S. Constitution]] prohibits members of the Senate or House from holding positions within the Executive Branch (Art. I, Sec. 6, cl. 2), and limits the president to his salary as chief executive, saying he may not "receive... any other Emolument from the United States, or any of them" (Art. II, Sec. 1, cl. 7).
===Florida=== In April 1984, [[Governor of Florida]] [[Bob Graham]] received legislation that passed unanimously in both houses of the [[Florida Legislature]] that would forbid public officials from receiving retirement pay and regular pay simultaneously for the same position.<ref>via ''[[Associated Press]]''. [https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=fvEcAAAAIBAJ&sjid=tmgEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5554,4531744 "Governor Receives Legislation to Halt 'Double Dipping'"], ''[[Sarasota Herald-Tribune]]'', April 19, 1984. Accessed May 30, 2010.</ref>
===Illinois=== In August 2008, [[Governor of Illinois]] [[Rod Blagojevich]] proposed legislation that would prohibit dual-office holding as part of changes to the state's ethics bill, stating that "dual government employment creates the potential for a conflict of interest because a legislator's duties to his or her constituents and his or her public employer are not always consistent." Critics, such as Representative [[Susana Mendoza]], called the actions "spite" on the part of the governor.<ref>Fusco, Chris. [http://www.suntimes.com/news/1137005,CST-NWS-doubledip31.article "Right thing to do -- or is it revenge?"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080912161045/http://www.suntimes.com/news/1137005,CST-NWS-doubledip31.article |date=2008-09-12 }}, ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'', August 31, 2008. Accessed May 30, 2010.</ref>
===New Jersey=== Fulfilling a campaign pledge that he had made when first running for the [[New Jersey Legislature]], [[Jack Sinagra]] sponsored a bill passed by the [[New Jersey Senate]] in 1992 that would ban the practice. At the time that the legislation first passed, there were some twenty elected officials who served in the New Jersey Legislature and another elected office, including Assemblyman [[Bill Pascrell]], who was also mayor of [[Paterson, New Jersey]]; State Senator [[Ronald Rice]], who also served on the [[Newark, New Jersey|Newark]] City Council; and Assemblyman [[John E. Rooney (politician)|John E. Rooney]], who was also mayor of [[Northvale, New Jersey|Northvale]]. These officials protested the proposed ban as interfering with the will of voters to elect officials as they see fit.<ref>Strum, Charles. [https://www.nytimes.com/1992/12/27/nyregion/new-jersey-politicians-serve-public-twice.html "New Jersey Politicians Serve Public, Twice"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', December 27, 1992. Accessed May 30, 2010.</ref> A newspaper called former State senator [[Wayne R. Bryant]] the "king of double dipping" because he was collecting salaries from as many as four public jobs he held simultaneously.<ref>[http://www.njjewishnews.com/njjn.com/050406/commLittleHopeForChange.html Little hope for change with the foxes still in charge], ''[[New Jersey Jewish News]]'', May 30, 2010.</ref>
[[Governor of New Jersey]] [[Jon Corzine]] signed legislation in September 2007 that banned the practice statewide, but the 19 legislators holding multiple offices as of February 1, 2008, were grandfathered into the system and allowed to retain their positions.<ref name="2008ban">[http://www.nj.com/south/index.ssf/2008/03/doubledipping_continues_increa.html "Double-dipping continues, increases after ban"], ''South Jersey Media Group'', March 24, 2008. Accessed Sep 7, 2012. "Since Gov. Jon S. Corzine signed a ban on dual-office holding in September, the number of lawmakers who hold more than one office has actually increased -- from 17 to 19 -- according to a report by The Star-Ledger of Newark. This is because a grandfather clause allows any lawmaker holding two offices as of Feb. 1 to keep both."</ref> As of January 2013, only four of the nineteen (listed in bold) continue to hold a dual mandate.<ref name=update>Arca, Matthew. [http://www.politickernj.com/60699/dual-office-holders-four-remain "Dual office holders: Four remain"], PolitickerNJ, Oct 26, 2012. Accessed Oct 30, 2012.</ref> :'''Name, Party-County – Second Public Office:''' Senators: *[[Dana Redd]], D-Camden – Councilwoman, [[Camden, New Jersey|Camden]] *'''[[Nicholas Sacco]], D-Hudson – Mayor, [[North Bergen, New Jersey|North Bergen]]''' *'''[[Paul Sarlo]], D-Bergen – Mayor, [[Wood-Ridge, New Jersey|Wood-Ridge]]''' *[[Robert Singer (American politician)|Robert Singer]], R-Ocean – Committeeman, [[Lakewood Township, New Jersey|Lakewood]] *'''[[Brian P. [https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=HYUUAAAAIBAJ&sjid=wwMEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6588,2817083 "House tries to forbid double dipping"], ''[[Toledo Blade]]'', February 9, 2001. Accessed May 30, 2010.</ref>
